Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The family requires money for daily living expenses, and the parent needs to provide it
Expectation2: Write clear and detailed legal opinions and orders.
Situation2: You need to draft a standard scheduling order for a new case, which is due by the end of the week.
Story: I sit at my desk, the glow of my computer screen illuminating the stack of case files waiting for my attention. As a judge, I know I must draft a scheduling order for a new case by the end of the week—my reputation depends on the clarity and thoroughness of my legal opinions. Yet, my phone buzzes with a message from my spouse: “We’re short on groceries again. Can you pick up some extra work this month?” The kids’ school fees are due soon, and the rent is looming. I feel the weight of my family’s needs pressing down on me, the expectation that I will keep us afloat financially. But overtime at the courthouse means less time for careful writing, and rushing my orders could compromise my integrity as a judge. My mind races, torn between the duty to my family and the demands of my profession. I stare at the blank document, heart pounding, knowing I can’t give both roles what they deserve at the same time.
